text: an opera is a multivalent crazy art form
and you find that when you make one
thing a given everything else moves
around it so if it's this Opera's going
to start this suprano suddenly the date
moves to a time that she's available the
repertoire becomes something that she's
comfortable with the room becomes a
theater that's appropriate to her Etc
the cast becomes a cast that supports
her it's odd that one given makes
everything else move around it and the
same was true that the given was I was
going to come to this company and we
were going to produce operas and
everything else we had to figure out the
difficulty was that the turnaround plan
really didn't wasn't feasible it
contained uh wishful thinking on the
revenue side that meant that it wasn't
sustainable and so I needed to look very
carefully at what the realities were and
I had the sense in the first year like
how is it that my predecessors were able
to do 16 operas for $40 million and I
can't do five operas for $30 million the
answer was that they didn't do 16 opers
for $40 million they ran very very large
deficits every year oddly though
troubling that information was it was a
relief because it meant I wasn't being
held to a standard that was unachievable
um rather that it cost more money the
flip side of that was that I knew
because I put on operas from the ground
up I know what everything costs in an
opera and so if I were walking down the
street and somebody handed me $30
million and said hey can you do five
operas kid answer is five how how about
10 how about 15 of course I can do that
but here was a company that had a
gigantic cost structure of overhead and
Opera is an overhead business um it's
really a 19th century kind of business
but in this case the overhead had eaten
the company alive there was nothing left
to make art with in fact there was
insufficient money just to stand
perfectly still so the task was to look
at the overhead to completely
restructure it and to put as much of the
money on stage as we possibly could and
that is kind of was a kind of thrilling
problem to discover and to work out a
solution for if you look around the
country there are two kinds of Opera
Company there are the big ones that have
big contracts and there are all the
others uh the big ones are the
Metropolitan Opera Chicago Lyric Opera
San Francisco Opera and New York City
Opera if we look back when New York City
Opera was doing its most amount of work
metalon Opera was doing about 24
Productions a season on a $300 million
budget Chicago Lyric Opera was doing
let's say eight Productions a season
roughly on a $60 million budget so much
smaller San Francisco is doing those
eight Productions around for $880
million and New York City Opera was
doing 16 productions for $40 million it
was a huge amount of work with very very
little money in our new size having cut
out all this overhead we're doing five
Productions on a $13 million budget so
it's just a much much smaller company so
we have to reshape the contracts we have
to match the new reality our old
contracts you buy time by the week uh
and you pay everybody whether they work
or not so if you want the orchestra you
can't have a flute you have all 60 or 70
members of the orchestra you can't have
them for 10 minutes you can't have them
for an hour you can't have them for 3
hours you have to buy them for a week
that makes sense if the amount of work
you're doing is higher than that
guaranteed minimum but it is crushing to
the organization if the amount of work
you're doing is in fact below that
minimum you end up spending money on
people not working and while it's
extremely difficult for the people who
are used to getting the money to
suddenly not get the money um there's no
way the company could continue without
that change for us it's very important
to be focused on what what goes on the
stage and what is behind the stage
what's the administrative cost and at
New York City Opera the overhead had
grown to be gigantic and what was left
over to put on the stage was Tiny and
those overhead costs grow and grow and
grow they have their own people
motivating the cost to grow each cost
area has a vocal champion who wants that
cost area to be bigger and bigger and
bigger but ultimately the success or
failure of the company is about putting
wonderful art on the stage and so uh one
needs to go through the budget area by
area to find out what really matters and
what doesn't matter and also to respond
to the exterior economy uh in ways that
make sense you know there are different
solutions for every different economic
situation
